unit_learning_outcomes.description: Name and define the common symptoms and signs that are associated with diseases of the body systems named above
Differentiate between diseases on the basis of aetiology, pathogenesis, epidemiology and clinical manifestations
For each disease studied, explain the relationship between its aetiology, pathogenesis and clinical manifestations
Apply knowledge of anatomy, physiology, biochemistry and basic pathology, to develop the likely mode of progression of the diseases studied in this unit
Name the range of pathologies that can occur in each of the following systems: Cardiovascular, Respiratory, Lymphatic, Haematopoietic, Endocrine, Immune, Digestive, Urinary and Reproductive
Explain the multifactorial nature in the development of disease states
Describe the aetiology, epidemiology, pathogenesis and clinical manifestations for each disease studied
Explain the pathophysiological processes which can alter an individual's health status

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Preparing answers to tutorial questions 2hrs per week weeks 2-13
Weekly reading from textbook and lecture materials  5hrs a week week 2-13

assessments.description: Quizzes during weeks 4, 6, 9, 11 and 13. Each quiz will be of 10 minutes duration, and cover material that has been delivered in lectures and/or tutorials
This will cover the content of the first half of the semester. Questions will be in short answer format.

assessments.assessment_title: End of semester final written examination
assessments.description: This will cover the content of the entire semester. Questions will include multiple choice and short answer questions

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 1, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 1, Special circumstances
data.description: This unit provides students with the opportunity to explore the relationship between health and disease, from both the biological and psychosocial perspective. The common pathologies of each body system are studied, and their causes, mechanisms and effects are explored. The links between these disease mechanisms and their clinical manifestations is highlighted. By the completion of this unit, students will have a good knowledge of the major diseases of the body, and how they manifest in the patient. By studying a large number of human disease states, students will deepen their understanding of the complex relationship between ourselves and our environment.
data.title: Medical Sciences A
